detailedSummary: Spanish has two past tenses with different uses. The preterite (pretérito) describes completed actions with specific beginnings/ends: 'Ayer comí pizza' (Yesterday I ate pizza). Regular preterite endings: -ar verbs use -é, -aste, -ó, -amos, -asteis, -aron; -er/-ir verbs use -í, -iste, -ió, -imos, -isteis, -ieron. The imperfect (imperfecto) describes ongoing, habitual, or background actions: 'Cuando era niño, jugaba fútbol' (When I was a child, I played soccer). Regular imperfect endings: -ar verbs use -aba, -abas, -aba, -ábamos, -abais, -aban; -er/-ir verbs use -ía, -ías, -ía, -íamos, -íais, -ían. Key differences: preterite = completed, specific time, one-time events; imperfect = ongoing, habitual, background, descriptions. Many sentences use both: 'Mientras estudiaba (imperfect), sonó (preterite) el teléfono' (While I was studying, the phone rang). Common irregular preterites: ser/ir (fui, fuiste, fue, fuimos, fuisteis, fueron), hacer (hice, hiciste, hizo, hicimos, hicisteis, hicieron). Mastering both past tenses enables detailed storytelling and accurate time expression.
whyItMatters: The preterite and imperfect are essential for talking about the past - understanding their differences enables accurate storytelling and expressing when and how past events occurred.

assignments.title: Master Past Tenses
assignments.description: Practice using preterite and imperfect correctly to describe past events.
tasks: Conjugate regular verbs in both preterite and imperfect tenses
Write 20 sentences using preterite for completed actions
Write 20 sentences using imperfect for ongoing/habitual actions
Create a story using both tenses together correctly
Practice irregular preterite verbs (ser, ir, hacer, tener, estar)

quizzes.question: When do you use preterite vs imperfect?
options: Preterite for ongoing actions, imperfect for completed actions
Preterite for completed actions with specific times, imperfect for ongoing/habitual actions
quizzes.explanation: Preterite describes completed actions with specific beginnings/ends, while imperfect describes ongoing, habitual, or background actions.

quizzes.question: The same verb can be used in both preterite and imperfect in the same sentence to show different aspects of an action.
quizzes.explanation: True. Sentences often combine both tenses: 'Mientras caminaba (imperfect - ongoing), vi (preterite - completed) un pájaro' shows background action interrupted by a specific event.

quizzes.question: What is the preterite form of 'ir' (to go) for 'yo'?
quizzes.explanation: 'Fui' is the preterite form of 'ir' for 'yo' (I went). Note that 'ser' and 'ir' have identical preterite forms.
